sentences.sentence: Last week the Canadian government renewed its advisory against non-essential travel, capping a string of bad news for the travel business that started three weeks ago.

On November 30th Canada announced an additional requirement for testing international air travellers on arrival, and two days later, the U.S. Centers for Disease Control and Prevention shortened the testing timeline for all international air travelers to the U.S from 72 hours to 24 hours before departure.

Finally, just last week, Canada reinstated the PCR testing requirement for U.S. cross-border trips of less than 72 hours.Canada's broader aviation industry - including all members of the food chain: airlines, airports, ground transport, hoteliers, travel agents, tourism bodies, hospitality, events management, tour operators, entertainment venues, and more - has suffered a massive decline in activity, revenues, and employment since the onset of the pandemic.Advance bookings to sun destinations this winter and to Europe next summer were strengthening and set to deliver a much needed shot in the arm for business.
Canadians boosted domestic tourism this past summer, but many were now saying, "Enough, we need a break and we want to get away somewhere warm or further afield.
"Recent government mandates, from travel bans and restrictions to blanket advisories, now threaten our already weakened aviation and travel sectors just as traction and recovery were in sight.
Since last week's announcement, a fall-off in advance bookings that started two weeks ago is being compounded by a wave of costly airline and ground cancellations.

For the average consumer, travel has gotten too complicated again and plans for it are being punted further down the proverbial runway.Many Canadians' natural risk aversion manifests itself institutionally through nanny-state decision-making.
The latest travel advisory continues the trend of reactive, knee-jerk announcements from paternalistic politicians who act as if only government knows best.

The political theatre of leaders taking bold, decisive action is displacing common sense and data-driven policy making.Moreover, Canada's travel measures continue to be out of synch with border policies put in place in other countries.
For example, we are one of only a few countries requiring passengers to submit to PCR testing both prior to returning home and upon arrival.
The most egregious difference lies at the U.S. land border.
Canadians are not required to show a pre-trip COVID test and U.S. officials may, at their discretion, only ask for proof of vaccination.
With over 50 per cent of Canadians living within 200 kilometres of a U.S. border airport, our industry is again leaking valuable air passengers to cross-border airports and U.S. airlines.
All of this hurts our citizens and our businesses.
We are eroding Canada's competitive position globally.Canadian government policies are also at odds with the reality on the ground.

Our aviation sector has been at the forefront of many safety developments, including required passenger masking, social distancing, PPE for inflight crew and airport agents, stringent airport and aircraft cleanliness protocols, and requirements for staff to be fully vaccinated in advance of the government-mandated vaccination rule for passengers travelling on any federally regulated transportation system.All of this, along with pre-departure testing, arrival testing, and the high degree of effectiveness of aircraft HEPA air filtering, means that air travel is one of the most tested and protective consumer activities in the country.
Which makes the latest measures all the more galling: the Omicron COVID variant is already in Canada and spreading at its own rapid pace.

It's too late to keep it out by closing the border.William Watson: A true-blue industry minister would quit(https://financialpost.com/opinion/william-watson-a-true-blue-industry-minister-would-quit)Joe Oliver: The fiscal update - you reap what you sow(https://financialpost.com/opinion/joe-oliver-the-fiscal-update-you-reap-what-you-sow)Opinion: Leaving 2021 - Longstanding problems could be addressed in 2022(https://financialpost.com/opinion/opinion-leaving-2021-longstanding-problems-could-be-addressed-in-2022)Further restrictions on air travel will not make Canada a safer place.

We've been through that already: forcing Canada's major airlines to suspend flights to all sun destinations between January and April of this year did not stop Canada's third COVID wave.Right now, it seems as if Ottawa wants you, the traveller, to be fearful of travel - as if we cannot decide for ourselves whether travelling beyond Canada's shores during a pandemic is a risk worth taking.

Most of us get it: border rules and travel restrictions are fluid, and there is the risk of catching COVID and having to quarantine, at cost, for up to two weeks while away from home.But for heaven's sake, after nearly two years of the pandemic, give Canadians credit: we should have some control over our own travel destinies and try to avoid further needless harm to the industry.Confidence in air travel has been dealt a devastating blow, and we in the business are going to suffer more for some time to come.

Vacation plans will be cancelled, family reunions delayed, business deals compromised, and some travel sector participants will again lay off employees and face worsening outcomes, up to and including failure.We can and should do better.
Much better.Robert J. Kokonis is president and managing director of AirTrav Inc., an aviation and travel management consulting firm based in Toronto.
@COPYRIGHT=© 2021 Postmedia Network Inc. All rights reserved.

documents.result_message: Our detector is moderately confident that the text is written entirely by a human.
